awd_titl_txt: POSE: Phase I:  Scoping the Ecosystem of Skyhook Data Management
awd_abstract_narration:
New, fast-moving open source ecosystems centered on big data and data science have emerged due to the successful business models in hyperscale computing industries. This Phase 1 project explores sustainable and effective pathways for establishing open source as an alternative translation for technologies using Skyhook as a pilot project. The project will coordinate a series of workshops convening open source experts and community leaders with diverse backgrounds to build expertise for open tech transfer within the university. An important focus in these workshops is the ability to foster a diverse community and encourage participation from historically excluded communities. The project seeks to impacts the adoption of Skyhook technology for reproducible research prototyping, as a teaching tool in classrooms, and for the establishment of open source as a viable translation path of technologies for research universities.

Apache Arrow is a representation of columnar data in memory which has created a wide-ranging and rapidly growing open source ecosystem of efficient data processing with many different programming language bindings (e.g., C, C++, C#, Go, Java, JavaScript, Julia, MATLAB, Python, R, Ruby, and Rust). Due to the common representation, data can move efficiently without conversion between the ecosystem's processing engines running on different systems.  Skyhook aims to become a research prototyping ecosystem and a blueprint for efficiently embedding data processing libraries in storage systems and computational storage devices while enabling processing and storage ecosystems to evolve independently.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The “Scoping the Ecosystem of Skyhook Data Management” Phase I project investigated viable pathways for establishing a sustainable open source ecosystem around an academic originating project that allows a significant improvement in the management of growing data sets for users in business, government and the sciences. In particular the SkyhookDM OSE lowers the costs of moving data in order to allow for open source products such as AI models, visualizations, and dashboards to be created. Among many computational I/O stack research and industry activities the SkyhookDM created a viable ecosystem of contributors and users. In particular, SkyhookDM and its community represents an alternative innovation path to current industry practices: large component makers and public cloud service providers focusing on low-risk proprietary and secret custom solutions, locking out academia, government, independent entrepreneurship, creating vendor lock-in, and stunting the development of new markets. Based on the success of this project, SkyhookDM has the foundation to start such an ecosystem, and a growing community of contributors and users poised to work on SkyhookDM as the infrastructure further develops.

 

With the support of this grant, the SkyhookDM project team tapped the knowledge of a wide wide set of stakeholders with expertise in creating and maintaining open source communities and leveraged established OS projects to create a sustainable pathway for SkyhookDM to move forward. Apart from the specific needs of the SkyhookDM, the project team – which included members of the Open Source Program Office (OSPO) at UC Santa Cruz (UCSC) – was also able to use their experience with this Phase 1 project to support and further the efforts of other burgeoning open source projects originating at UCSC and increase the understanding of the value of open source in the university’s research enterprise. 

 

An important tangible outcome of this project was a series of workshops that identified SkyhookDM developers and users, and connected them with open source experts from industry, civil society and academia. These events lowered the barriers to Skyhook adoption both inside and outside academia, as well as identify how a SkyhookDM OSE should be structured to ensure long-term success. This project also looked toward creating a guiding principle of sustainably supporting the innovative technology within SkyhookDM that would enable growth of a diverse community around it. Project activities – workshops, community meetings and presentations to wider open source communities – helped the project team identify unique pathways for other academic products -- including non-comercial routes -- to follow in furthering their research's wider societal impact.


Last Modified: 12/31/2024
Modified by: Stephanie C Lieggi
